Top Nine Film Soundtracks to Help You Through the Christmas Period

12/12/2020

Georgia Strong recommends some of her favourite film soundtracks to listen to over Christmas.

Image by Universal Pictures

By Kristina Wemyss

Here are some popular film soundtracks that I have chosen for December 2020. As you can see, I have resisted the urge to list only Christmas films, because if you go anywhere near the shops as soon as the lockdown is lifted, you will undoubtedly be inundated with Christmas music. All featured albums are available on Spotify.

For the journey home from university: War Horse by John Williams

Listen in particular to â€˜The Reunionâ€™

This might be a sad one, but this year has been tough. If you listen to the entire album, the order of the tracks sort of mirrors the year 2020 in terms of mood; it starts out with the horse, Joey being bought at the auction, bonding with Jeremy Irvine and then slowly things get a little more depressing as he is sold to Tom Hiddleston, who takes him to war. Listen to the above for a triumphant return to your hometown, where youâ€™re the main character, of course.

https://open.spotify.com/track/30NmHX5FFdYruSW3DkoSZ1?si=6mhliRT3R_-QLQc6n4zGCA

For when youâ€™ve exhausted the Dark Academia side of TikTok: Romeo and Juliet by Abel Korzeniowski

Listen in particular to â€˜Forbidden Loveâ€™

Now, unless you have been on a very niche side of TikTok, you will have come across the term â€˜Dark Academia.â€™ It is aimed at those who like to read and wear dark clothing. These numerous TikToks have been using sumptuous romantic film scores to accompany their creators running through the streets of Edinburgh, pretending theyâ€™re in films. Korzeniowskiâ€™s signature instrumentation of piano and strings is just the thing for the hopeless romantics. See also on TikTok or Pinterest: Cottagecore.

https://open.spotify.com/track/5UNOpPQH4SejKARfqRbk8N?si=ldE8iEELTui2ixegt9Y-Rw

For escapism: Peter Pan by James Newton Howard

Listen in particular to â€˜Flyingâ€™

You would be lying if you said this track did not make you want to escape to Neverland. Aside from the questionable relationship Captain Hook seemed to have with Wendy, this film pretty much summed up the childhood we all wish we had had. This lively soundtrack will make even the toughest sceptic shout, â€œI do believe in fairies.â€

https://open.spotify.com/track/4GpQYHObZfQrninpJPMoFX?si=EcnE42fRSNKRuFO22hmuyw

For when youâ€™re untangling the Christmas lights: The Polar ExpressÂ by Alan Silvestri

Listen in particular to â€˜Seeing is Believingâ€™

This score is quintessentially Christmas, complete with sleigh-bells and carols mixed into this one track alone. The main theme symbolises the doubts a young boy has about Christmas. Is it all just a marketing ploy? Well, the soundtrack says not. We are taken on a journey of self-discovery, guided by the trainâ€™s conductor voiced by Tom Hanks and featuring a ghost who looks suspiciously like Sean Bean. The film score incorporates awe and wonder into the melodies using a minor key for the main theme â€“ unconventional for Christmas films.

https://open.spotify.com/track/0AHlbD95hYzP5Fgj0F69OI?si=IXvdQzlBQw6_IHYClvTHQw

For wallowing in self-pity like the Grinch: War and Peace by Martin Phipps

Listen in particular to â€˜Give Thanksâ€™

The score for this miniseries is clearly heavily influenced by Rachmaninovâ€™s Vespers. Using voices so low you can barely hear them, Phippsâ€™ score is an envelope of sound, a musical embrace. â€˜Give Thanksâ€™ is the culmination of six episodes of suffering; it is the final resolution of hardship all the characters experience.

https://open.spotify.com/track/1gPIiZ9NJUuNK9ayGsg9tg?si=3Q5uJUb4R3uLa8lQhVIpqA

For that sudden urge to do a workout: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King by Howard Shore

Listen in particular to â€˜The Battle of the Pelennor Fieldsâ€™

Honestly, I could have chosen any one of the epic battle scene musical moments from the trilogy; they are all so stirring. However, there is something about the build up from low brass and strings to heavy percussion and finally the Rohirrim theme, that makes you feel invincible. Recommended for the last leg of your run for some extra motivation.

https://open.spotify.com/track/2pSMjadGmWcUbIF5eqLUxE?si=RqAQ53klQEudC6l2Z_ABcA

For some nostalgia: Finding Nemo by Thomas Newman

Listen in particular to â€˜Nemo Eggâ€™

Alright, so this soundtrack might not seem nostalgic to some, but Thomas Newman, who created some of the best scores for the Nineties, brought this charm over into the Noughties. Newman is best known for his simple piano parts written over strings. Upon hearing this, you are instantly transported into that blue animated ocean that is recognisable to so many of us. Hopefully, this is before the barracuda turns up.

https://open.spotify.com/track/7jSQaXLzpLHjSQTev2krvT?si=D68A_xUfS8OPIKrNtwgv4A

For getting through cuffing season: The Holiday by Hans Zimmer

Listen in particular to â€˜Maestroâ€™

We all adore the Love Actually soundtrack, and we can never forgive Alan Rickman for making Emma Thompson cry, but letâ€™s shine some light on The Holiday. This soundtrack has the ability to simultaneously make you feel alone and optimistic about finding love. Itâ€™s Cameron Diaz running through snow in heels to tell Jude Law she canâ€™t be without him just through the music alone. Unlike some of the other soundtracks on this list, thereâ€™s some upbeat jazzy moments cleverly interspersed with the main theme by Hans Zimmer. Itâ€™s both tender and playful at the same time; the perfect Christmas rom-com soundtrack.

https://open.spotify.com/track/4SimUIFxXh5N6VsF33oMo7?si=DMYTItryQa-Lvzb0qWH3Gg

For comfort: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets by John Williams

Listen in particular to â€˜Reunion of Friendsâ€™

I recommend all of the Harry Potter film soundtracks for escaping the mundane existence we all find ourselves in right now, but the first three films are the most comforting. During both lockdowns, many people returned to their favourite films for some kind of certainty. Now, John Williams uses many of the leitmotifs from the first film in this score which in turn, means that we are already familiar with them by the time the second film shows them. Take for example, the â€˜Leaving Hogwartsâ€™ track which is fully included in â€˜Reunion of Friendsâ€™ from the second film. At the end, it is embellished to create a wonderful feeling of homecoming, perfect for Christmas.

https://open.spotify.com/track/0rpSIjKSmZ2SFO6vmLJpXl?si=hJXSAvuVQV2IHeW_32cRIA
